comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: This seems likely to be a electric-motor bus proposed by the Electro-Coach Corporation as an alternative to buses run by the Fifth Avenue Coach Company powered by gasoline. See books.google.com/books?id=bfUfAQAAMAAJ&pg=RA23-PA43&a...

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: There is an article in The Day book (March 13, 1915, NOON EDITION, Image 4) about it: "JITNEYS IN NEW YORK! ELECTRIC BUSES ARE RUNNING WITH GIRL CONDUCTORS Miss Alice Scanlon, and the luxurious electric bus in which she is conductor. This is one of several buses running in New York today as an advertisement, without passengers. If the company gets its franchise, the buses will afford as cheap transportation as the street cars, and much more comfortable." chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045487/1915-03-13/ed-...

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: An article of The New York Times from November 14, 1913 about the plans to establish the project: "T.A. EDISON FAVORS ELECTRIC BUSES; Five-Cent Fare Concern Quotes Inventor in Asking for a Franchise in This City. IT FACES A HARD FIGHT Other Traction Concerns and Property Owners Oppose Application Before the Board of Estimate. Armed with a letter from Thomas A. Edison setting forth the inventor's belief that the future of urban transportation lay with electrically driven vehicles, the People's Five-Cent Bus Company, which is backed by Congressman-elect George W. Loft, the candy manufacturer, came yesterday before the Board of Estimate and asked for a franchise to run omnibus lines through the city." query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0914F63A5813738... I could not find out how this project ended.
